title: Multiple Maniacs
descriptions:
Multiple Maniacs (1970) follows Lady Divine, the ferocious, foul-mouthed ringmaster of a ramshackle traveling sideshow called “The Cavalcade of Perversion,” which lures curious onlookers with promises of taboo spectacles before robbing them at gunpoint. When Divine’s long-suffering lover, Mr. David, conspires with a younger woman to betray her, Divine spirals into deranged vengeance, careening through Baltimore on a rampage that blurs performance, crime, and apocalyptic melodrama.

After a humiliating double-cross, Divine flees and encounters a mysterious woman in a church, leading to a blasphemous, hallucinatory tryst that heightens her sense of messianic madness. Convinced she is both sinner and avenger, Divine returns to settle scores, targeting her faithless troupe and any bystanders unlucky enough to cross her path. The film escalates as Divine’s fury transforms the city into a stage for grotesque set pieces: humiliations, confrontations, and violent outbursts that skewer middle-class sensibilities and sanctimony.

As police close in, Divine’s paranoia and grandiosity fuse into a surreal crescendo. Her rampage becomes both a personal reckoning and a campy, anarchic satire of American moral panic. The line between spectacle and reality collapses—the sideshow’s staged perversions give way to genuine chaos—and Divine embraces a monstrous, unstoppable persona. In a jaw-dropping finale, she is pursued through the streets, howling and blood-spattered, culminating in a delirious, creature-like rampage that is as tragic as it is outrageous.

John Waters’ rough-hewn, black-and-white underground feature uses shock humor, sacrilege, and gleeful bad taste to lampoon hypocrisy and repression. The plot, while simple—betrayal, revenge, and downfall—is driven by Divine’s towering performance, a whirlwind of rage, lust, and theatrical bravado. Multiple Maniacs captures a carnivalesque vision of America where every boundary—sexual, religious, and social—is bait for a punchline or a provocation, and where the pursuit of vengeance becomes a midnight-movie myth about the corrupting thrill of transgression.
